string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

search.slidetext: the writing situation the communication situation the rhetorical situation class goal: analyze and produce texts that are guided by situational awareness audience purpose context genre

audience speaker recipient active participant can misinterpret speaker recipient active participant can misinterpret what is my relationship to my audience? what do i want my relationship with them to be?

purpose what does my audience want? how can i align my purposes to the audience’s desires? what obstacles are getting between my audience and their desires or my purpose? how can my communication remove or lessen those obstacles? layers of purpose get the job get to the next communication opportunity express gratitude remind them of interest and excitement
purpose persuasion entertainment information/education become an “influencer” know your writing purpose share moments with friends

context context is the world outside of the writing assumptions in communication about: technology culture religion morality language ideas ideals what else has been said about your topic? what recent events have taken place? where am i while writing this? what does my reader know or believe?

why it matters increases the strength of communication increases the accuracy of communication economizes your communication makes you a better friend helps you avoid miscommunications gives you a professional superpower how do you convince someone to give your project a green light, or to promote you? how do you motivate people to work hard with and for you? if you’re a police officer, how do you calm down someone who’s a potential threat? if you’re a lawyer, how do you convince a judge or jury? if you’re a salesperson or marketer, how do you win over a customer? purpose audience context genre
genre which genre/format? video? text and audio? animation and interaction? options limited
